publicwhip.major-heading: Oral Answers to Questions — UNEMPLOYMENT.

speech.p: asked the Minister of Labour the number of acres of land that, have been purchased in Durham for land settlement schemes, the amount paid per acre, the number of families placed on full-time holdings, and the total cost of each holding up to date?

speech.speakername: The Minister of Labour (Mr. Ernest Brown)
speech.p: I would refer the hon. Member to the answer which I gave to him on 24th May, 1938. Since then, the number of families actually placed has been increased from 124 to 196. The particulars with regard to acreage and cost remain unchanged.
Is it the intention of the right hon. Gentleman or of the Commissioner for the Special Areas to purchase more land for this purpose?
I should want notice of that question.

asked the Minister of Labour the total number of unemployed in the county of Fife at the last available date; and how many of these have
been unemployed for three months, six months, one year, or two years or more?
As the reply includes a number of figures, I will, if I may, circulate it in the OFFICIAL REPORT.

At 13th February, 1939, there were 10,142 unemployed persons aged 14 and over on the registers of Employment Exchanges in the county of Fife, including 8,906 persons aged 16–64 applying for unemployment benefit or allowances.

An analysis of these applicants according to the length of the current spell of unemployment is given below:
Less than 3 months 4,757
3 months but less than 6 months 1,444
6 months but less than 12 months 727
1 year but less than 2 years 634
2 years or more 1,344
Of the persons who had been on the register for extended periods a proportion will have had one or more short spells of employment, lasting not more than three days each, during such periods.
Corresponding particulars are not available in respect of unemployed persons who are not applicants for benefit or allowances.

asked the Minister of Labour the number of agricultural workers registered as unemployed at the last available date in the county of Fife; and how many of these were in receipt of unemployment pay at the last convenient date?

At 13th February, 1939, there were 518 persons, aged 14–64, insured under the agricultural scheme who were recorded as unemployed at Employment Exchanges in the county of Fife. Of these 454 had applications for unemployment benefit under the agricultural or the general scheme or for allowances.

Does the Minister not recognise that there is a very serious situation in agriculture in Fife, and can he say whether any special efforts are being made to assist the agricultural industry there in finding employment?
That question should be addressed to my right hon. Friend the Minister of Agriculture.

asked the Minister of Labour how many married women in the city of Salford have been refused unemployment insurance benefit during the last 12 months; the causes for the loss of benefit; how many claims have been allowed on appeal to the court of referees; and how many refused on appeal?

Statistics regarding the disallowance of claims made by married women are available only in the case of disallowances under the Anomalies Order. Claims cannot be disallowed by the insurance officer under that Order, but must be referred to the court of referees. During the 12 months ended 28th February, 1939, 500 claims by married women at the Salford Employment Exchange were disallowed by the court of referees under the Order.

As the reply includes a number of figures, I will, if I may, circulate a statement in the OFFICIAL REPORT.

asked the Minister of Labour when the Government intend to introduce their proposed legislation to make loan facilities more readily available
for new undertakings in areas which are not scheduled as Special Areas under the Special Areas, Acts, but which are, nevertheless, suffering from heavy unemployment?
I am at present not in a position to add to the answer which I gave to the hon. Member for Llanelly (Mr. J. Griffiths) on 9th March.
How soon will the Minister be in a position to make an announcement on the subject? Action in this matter was promised four or five years ago.
I cannot give a date, but it will not be long.

asked the Minister of Labour under which regulation men are being summoned to the Burnley Employment Exchange merely for the purpose of answering questions as to their height and weight; and what is the purpose of these inquiries?
I am having inquiries made and will communicate with the hon. Member as soon as possible.
Does not the Minister know whether there are any regulations?
It is on that point that I am making inquiries.
Is it not possible to obtain the information by circulating forms to these men?
Is it not a serious matter that Employment Exchanges should do this kind of thing?
I should like to know what the particular cases are.
Is there a regulation that allows this to be done?

Until I have made inquiries and found what the facts are I do not know what they are, or what the purpose of the inquiry was. As soon as I get the result of my investigations I will let the House know.
It is not a case of that kind. May I—
rose—

On a point of Order. This is an important matter on which I should
like to get a definite reply from the Minister.
The Minister has said that he is making inquiries.

asked the Minister of Labour whether he will consider initiating schemes under which some of the unemployed can be absorbed for removing coal spoil heaps, especially in view of the deleterious effect which these have on people living nearby?

I have no funds at my disposal for this purpose outside the Special Areas. In these areas the Commissioner has made grants towards the cost of clearance and other schemes for improving the amenities of the district.
Is it not possible to extend this system elsewhere rather than in the Special Areas only, considering the necessity of the, case?
Will the right hon. Gentleman make an attempt to deal with the problem in the semi-depressed areas, which have as many unemployed as the Special Areas, and do it as quickly as he can?
I gather that that is the suggestion put forward by my hon. Friend.
asked the Minister of Labour whether he is yet in a position to make any statement as to the establishment of a training centre for unemployed men in or near Manchester?

Yes, Sir. I am taking steps to establish a local training centre in a central position on the borders of Manchester and Salford close to two main railway stations, which it is hoped that men living in and around any part of the Manchester area will be able to attend while living at home. I hope that this centre will be ready to begin training in May. The length of the training course will be from eight to 12 weeks and will have as its object to prepare men for employment in the new factories in the area.
How many men is that training centre made to accommodate?
I think about 200.
Will it be available to neighbouring towns within 10 or 12 miles?
As I have said, this centre is being established close to two main railway stations.

asked the Minister of Labour whether all applicants who are granted money to buy clothing or boots have to refund the money at so much per week; and whether this payment is stopped out of their allowance?
No, Sir. The cases in which grants are made subject to adjustment of future weekly allowances are very exceptional.

asked the Minister of Labour under what Clause in the Unemployment Assistance Board regulations or other authority officers of the Board are acting when they send applicants to make an application for clothing to a charitable organisation for clothing that they want?
I am informed that it is the general practice of the Board to refer applicants to voluntary organisations only in cases where the need and requirement cannot appropriately be met from public funds.
asked the Minister of Labour whether when an applicant fills up a determination form for clothing he is always supplied with second-hand' clothing?
No, Sir. In practically all cases grants are made in cash.

As the reply includes a number of figures, I will, if I may, circulate a statement in the OFFICIAL REPORT.

The figure for 13th February, 1939, includes 4,560 persons, aged 16–64, applying for unemployment benefit or allowances. The following table analyses this figure according to the length of the current spell of unemployment of these persons:
